div2.stage: Enter CALLICLES, attended by SLAVES, with his MAID-SERVANT and SYRA, bound.

note.#text: :  " Tintinnaculos." The executioners or torturers are so called, either from their putting fetters on the persons to be punished, or else from their fastening bells (tintinnabula) upon them, to prevent their running away.

p.#text: . Do I use ill language to you, or do I wish you so very ill? According to my ideas, you have both pretty well experienced how mild and gentle a person I am. I interrogated you both, as you were lashed and hanging up by the arms; I well remember it; the way in which you quite confessed each point, I know. Here now, I wish in the same way to learn; do you confess without a punishment. Although you are both of you of the serpent nature, I tell you beforehand, you mustn't be having double tongues, lest with your two tongues I should be putting you to death; unless, perhaps, you wish to be taken to the men who go clink, clink.

sp.speaker: A MAID-SERVANT of Callicles.
sp.p: Violence forces me to confess the truth; the thongs do so gall my arms.

sp.speaker: CALLICLES
sp.p: But, if you confess the truth to me, you shall be relieved from the chains.

p.#text: . Even now, what's the matter, I'm at a loss to know and uncertain; except that still I'm afraid.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: What I've done wrong I know not.

p.#text: First of all, then, you stand apart.  Aye, so; that's what I mean; that you mayn't be making signs between you, I'll be a party-wall.  Speak you.

sp.speaker: A MAID-SERVANT of Callicles.
sp.p: What am I to speak about?

sp.speaker: CALLICLES
sp.p: What was done with the child that my daughter was delivered of? My grandchild, I mean? Tell me the circumstances of the case.

p.#text: I gave it to her.
. Now hold your tongue.  Did you receive the child from her?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: I did receive it.

p.#text: . Hold your tongue; I want no more; you've confessed enough.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: I'm not going to deny it.

sp.speaker: CALLICLES
sp.p: By this you've now caused some relief for your shoulder-blades. So far, the account of each of them tallies.

p.#text: . Ah wretched me! my doings are now being disclosed, which I hoped would be concealed.
. Speak, you. Who bade you give the child to her?

sp.speaker: A MAID-SERVANT of Callicles.
sp.p: My elder mistress.

p.#text: . What say you? Why did you receive it?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: My young mistress entreated me that the child might be brought, and that all this might remain secret.

p.#text: . Speak, you. What did you do with this child?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: I took it to my mistress.

sp.speaker: CALLICLES
sp.p: What did your mistress do with this child?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: Gave it at once to my mistress.

sp.speaker: CALLICLES
sp.p: Plague on it, to what mistress?

sp.speaker: A MAID-SERVANT of Callicles.
sp.p: There are two of them.

p.#text: . Take you care, unless I ask you anything, only to answer that which I ask of you.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: The mother, I say, made a present of it to the daughter.

sp.speaker: CALLICLES
sp.p: You are saying more than you did just now.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: You are asking more.

sp.speaker: CALLICLES
sp.p: Answer me quickly; what did she do, to whom it was given? Tell me.

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: She passed it off as----

sp.speaker: CALLICLES
sp.p: Whose?

sp.speaker: SYRA
sp.p: As her own son.

note.#text: :  Plautus must, of course, mean two grandmothers by the mother's side alone; otherwise there was nothing wonderful in a child having two grandmothers.

p.#text: As her own son? Ye Gods, by my trust in you I do appeal to you, how much more easily does another than she to whom it belongs, bring forth another's child! She, by the labours of another, has brought forth this child without pain. A child blest indeed! two mothers it has got, and grandams two. I'm now afraid how many fathers there may have been. Do see, please, the shocking deeds of women!

sp.speaker: A MAID-SERVANT of Callicles.
sp.p: I' troth, this fraud relates rather to the men than to the women. 'Twas a man, and not a woman, that caused her pregnancy.

sp.speaker: CALLICLES
sp.p: I know that too. You were a trusty guardian for it.

sp.speaker: A MAID-SERVANT of Callicles.
sp.p: He can do the most, who is strong the most. He was a man; he was the strongest; he prevailed; what he wanted, he carried off.

sp.speaker: CALLICLES
sp.p: And, i' faith, he too brought a heavy mishap, in fact, upon yourself.

sp.speaker: A MAID-SERVANT of Callicles.
sp.p: The thing itself experienced, I myself fully know that, even if you had held your tongue.

sp.speaker: CALLICLES
sp.p: Never, this day, have I been able to made you declare who he was.

p.stage: aside, on catching sight of DINARCHUS
p.#text: . I've held my tongue; but now I shan't hold my tongue, since he's here; it's necessary I should tell.

. I'm petrified; in my wretchedness, I dare not move myself; the matter's all out! The trial's now going on here for my life! These are my misdeeds, this is my folly. I'm in dread how soon I may be named.
. Speak out, who was it, debauched my maiden daughter?

sp.speaker: A MAID-SERVANT of Callicles.
sp.p: I see him near you.

sp.speaker: CALLICLES
sp.p: Hussy, who was it?

note.#text: :  Dinarchus, in his fright, is sneaking close to the wall. The servant espying him, sneeringly calls him "patronus parieti," "the patron" or "supporter of the wall."

p.#text: A supporter of the wall.
. I'm neither alive nor dead, nor know I what I am now to do; neither know I how to go away hence, nor how to accost him; I'm numbed with fear.

sp.speaker: CALLICLES
sp.p: Will you tell me, or no?

sp.speaker: A MAID-SERVANT of Callicles.
sp.p: It is Dinarchus, to whom you first betrothed her.

p.#text: . Where is this person whom you mention?

. Here I am, Callicles.  By your knees I do entreat you that you will bear with wisdom that which was done in folly; and that you will pardon me that, which, losing my senses, I did through the bad influence of wine.

note.#text: :  By throwing the blame on wine, that could not defend itself.

p.#text: You please me not. You throw the blame on what is dumb, that which cannot speak. But the wine, if it could speak, would defend itself. It's not wine that's in the habit of ruling men, but men wine; those, indeed, who are virtuous men; but he who is bad, although he drinks water, or if indeed he abstains from intoxicating liquors, still, by nature he's bad.

sp.speaker: DINARCHUS
sp.p: Well, I'm sensible that many reproaches must be heard by me, which I would prefer not. I confess that I've offended you, and am privy to the crime.

sp.speaker: A MAID-SERVANT of Callicles.
sp.p: Callicles, prithee beware that you do injury to no person; the accused is pleading his cause at large, the witnesses you are keeping in bonds.

stage: to each of them in turn
(SYRA goes into the house of PHRONESIUM, and exit the MAID-SERVANT.)
p.#text:
. Release those women.  Come , do you be off home, and you home as well.  Tell your mistress this. she must give up the child, if any one asks for it.

 You, Dinarchus, let's go before the judge.

sp.speaker: DINARCHUS
sp.p: Why do you wish me to go before the judge? You are the Prtor to me. But I entreat of you, Callicles, that you'll give me your daughter for a wife.

sp.speaker: CALLICLES
sp.p: I' faith, I find, indeed, that you've come to a decision on that point yourself; for you haven't waited till I gave her; you have helped yourself. Now keep her, as you've got her, but I'll fine you this grand haul; six great talents will I deduct from her dowry for this folly.

sp.speaker: DINARCHUS
sp.p: You act kindly towards me.

stage: Pointing to the house of PHRONESIUM.
p.#text: 'Twere best for you to demand your son back from thence.  But your wife, as soon as possible, take away from my house. I shall at once, therefore, send a messenger to that kinsman of mine by marriage, and tell him to look out for another match for his son.

. But I'll demand back the child of her, lest by-and-by she should deny it. That's of no use; for she herself, of her own accord, has discovered the whole matter to me, how it happened. But see, right opportunely, i' faith, is she coming out of doors from her house. Assuredly, a far-darting sting has that woman, who even from that distance is wounding my heart.

div2.stage: Enter PHRONESIUM and ASTAPHIUM, from the house of the former.

p.#text: . A woman is a spoony and a trolloping slut, if she hasn't a view to her own interests, even in her cups. If her other limbs are soaked in wine, at least let her head be sober. But it's a vexation to me that my hair-dresser has been thus badly treated. She has been telling me that this child has been discovered to be the son of dinarchus. When I heard that * * * *
. She's going, in whose hands are all my fortune and my children.
. I see him who has constituted me the guardian of his property.
. Madam, here am I.

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: It certainly is he. What's the matter, my love?

sp.speaker: DINARCHUS
sp.p: No love; cease your trifling. I've nothing now to do with that subject.

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: By my faith, I know what you want, and what you desire, and what you ask for. You want to see me; you desire to caress me; you ask for the child.

p.#text: . Immortal Gods! how plain she speaks. How, in a few words, has she hit upon the very point!

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: As for me, I know that you are betrothed, and that you have a son by your betrothed, and that a wife is now going to be married by you; that now your thoughts are elsewhere, that myself you are going to consider as forsaken. But still consider, the little mouse, how sagacious an animal it is, which never entrusts its life to one hole only; inasmuch as, if one hole is blocked up, it seeks another as a place of refuge.

sp.speaker: DINARCHUS
sp.p: When there's leisure, then I'll talk to you on those matters more at large; at present, give me up the child.

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: No; do, there's a dear, let it be at my house the few next days.

sp.speaker: DINARCHUS
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: Do, there's a dear.

sp.speaker: DINARCHUS
sp.p: What occasion is there?

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: It's for my interest. This for the next three days at least, until the Captain is circumvented somehow; for that same purpose. If I get anything, it shall be for your own advantage as well. If you take the child away, all hope in the Captain will evaporate from my heart.

note.#text: :  "Refacere." This, in most of the Editions, is printed as "re facere," "to do in reality;" but that does not seem to be the proper reading. Dinarchus appears to mean, "You may keep the child for the present, in order to carry out your plans; for when I have once taken it home I shall not be able to do it again"--or, in other words, "lend it to you for your purposes."

p.#text: I would have that done; but, when it's taken home, to do it again, if I were to wish it, I have not the opportunity. Now make use of the child, and take care of it, because you have the means by which to take care of it.

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: Upon my faith, I do love you much for this matter. When you shall be afraid of a scolding at home, do you take shelter here in my house. At least, prove a friend, to help me to a profitable speculation.

p.#text: . Kindly farewell, Phronesium.

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: Won't you any longer call me "apple of your eve?"

sp.speaker: DINARCHUS
sp.p: That name too, meanwhile, shall be repeated full oft.

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: Do you wish for anything else?

p.#text: Fare thee well; when I have leisure, I'll come to your house.

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: Well, he's gone away from here, and has taken his departure; we may say here whatever we please. 'Tis a true proverb that's quoted, "Where the friends are, there are the riches." Through him, there's still some hope that the Captain may be duped to-day; whom, by the powers, I love better than my own self,--so long as I get out of him what I want: since, when we have got much, not much of it is seen that has been given. Such are the brilliant prospects of Courtesans!

sp.speaker: ASTAPHIUM
sp.p: Hush! hush! be quiet.

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: Prithee, what is it?

sp.speaker: ASTAPHIUM
sp.p: The father of the child is coming.

p.#text: Well, let him come here. Let him, if it only is he, let him come himself straight up to me here just as he chooses. If he does come, for very sure, i' faith, I'll do him to-day with some cunning tricks.

div2.stage: PHRONESIUM and ASTAPHIUM appear before the door of the house.  Enter STRATOPHANES.

note.#text: :  "Eo mi amare." It is much more easy to guess at the sense of this passage, than at what is really the proper reading of it as it is evidently corrupt.

p.#text: . That I should love for this! I'm taking an atonement for my offences to my mistress! That that may be taken by her in kindly part which I've squandered before, I'll add this as well. But what's this? I see the mistress and her maid before the house. I must accost her.  What are you doing here?

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: Don't speak to me.

p.#text: You are too angry.

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: Leave me alone. Can't you possibly cease to be an annoyance to me?

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: What is the matter, my dear little Astaphium?

sp.speaker: ASTAPHIUM
sp.p: I' faith, she's angry with you with good reason.

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: What, I? I'm not even half spiteful enough to. wards that fellow.

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: My love, if I have at all offended before, I present you with this mina of gold. If you smile upon me, deign me a look.

note.#text: :  "Matri." Literally, "the mother."
:  Even in those days, nurses were famed for their toping propensities. See the Andria of Terence, l. 229.
:  It is not known whether "setanium" or "setanum" here means "medlars" or "onions." Some Commentators think it means an inferior kind of pulse, used as food for the children of the poor.

p.#text: My hand forbids me to believe anything, before it holds in its possession. We require food for the child; we require it for the dame as well, that bathes the child; we require it for the nurse, as well, that she may have a leather bottle full of old wine in ample style, that night and day she may tipple; we stand in need of fire; we want coals, too; we want swathes, napkins, the cradle, the cradle-bed; oil we want; the child requires flour, for pap; all day we are wanting something; never, in the same one day, can our task be performed, but what there's always need of something; for the children of officers cannot be reared upon medlars.
Look upon me then. Take this , with which to satisfy these necessities.
. Give it me, although it's very little.
Whatever you shall order, shall be given at your demand. Give me a kiss now.

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: Leave me alone, I say! You are a nuisance!

p.#text: . It's no use, I'm not loved by her; the day wears apace. More than ten pounds of silver have I lost in this short time by reason of my passion.
. Take this, and carry it away in-doors.

. Where in the world is my mistress? I get on with no business, either in the country or here, at this rate; I'm spoiling with mouldiness, I'm grown so dreadfully numbed with lying waiting here upon the couch. But look, I perceive her. Hallo! sweetheart, what are you about?

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: What fellow is that?

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: One that, upon my honor, I love far more than yourself.

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: Than myself? In what way?

p.#text: Why, this way, that you are not to be troublesome to me.

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: Are you going now, after you've got the gold?

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: What you've given me, I've put away in-doors.

sp.speaker: STRABAX
sp.p: Come here, sweetheart; I've got something to say to you.

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: Why, I was just coming to you.

sp.speaker: STRABAX
sp.p: To me, my charmer?

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: In serious truth, i' faith.

sp.speaker: STRABAX
sp.p: Although I seem a simpleton to you, I like myself to have a bit of recreation. For pretty though you are, you are so to your own loss, unless I amuse myself a bit with you.

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: Should you like me to embrace you and give you a kiss?

p.#text: Do whatever you like, I'll deem it agreable.

What, shall I suffer her to be embracing other men before my eyes? I' faith, 'twere better that I were dead. Woman, take your hands off of him, unless, perhaps, by this sword of mine, won from the enemy, you wish yourself and him to die.

note.#text: :   "to trifle," "to play upon;" almost exactly corresponding with our use of the French term "."

p.#text: There's no use in "badinage," Captain. If you want yourself to be loved, with gold, Stratophanes, not with iron, may you prevent him from loving me.

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: How, the plague, are you pretty or witty, to be fond of a fellow of that description?

p.#text: . Don't it come to your recollection what an actor once said upon the stage? " All people have an eye to their profit, and are not over delicate."

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: That you could possibly caress this fellow, so dirty and foul!

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: Although he is dirty, although he is foul, still, he's pretty to me.

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: Didn't I give you some gold?

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: To me? You gave money for the child's food.

sp.speaker: STRABAX
sp.p: Now, if you hope to have her, another mina of gold is requisite.

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: A sore mishap upon these people, and a weighty one!

sp.speaker: STRABAX
sp.p: By all means, keep that by way of provision for your own journey.

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: What does she owe you?

sp.speaker: STRABAX
sp.p: Three things.

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: What, pray?

sp.speaker: STRABAX
sp.p: Perfumes, her favours, and kisses.

p.#text: . He answers him like for like.  But now, at all events, if you do love me, do you give me some little trifle from your most abundant treasures.

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: Do say, there's a dear, what it is that I'm to give you; only say. If I have it left, you shall have it.

note.#text: :   This is from the Greek  "a caterpillar," and means "nonsensical, trifling stuff." He gives her a hint, in the next line, to beware of the great teeth of the countrymen.

p.#text: Mere kickshaws you're talking about. Be off, be off.

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: I've considered this over with myself. My good sir, take you care, will you, that she don't inflict a wound upon you, whose teeth are made of iron. She's allowing access to her to all in common. You take your hand off of her.

p.#text: . Then, by my troth, do you take that, with a hearty punch, warlike man!

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: I've given her gold.

sp.speaker: STRABAX
sp.p: And I, silver.

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: And I a mantle and a purple garment.

note.#text: :  "Melius, te minis certare mecum, quam minaciis." He plays upon the resemblance of the word "minis," "with min," to "minaciis," "with threats," and means that money is more likely than menaces to have weight with Phronesium.

p.#text: And I, sheep and wool; and many other things that she shall ask for I'll give. 'Twere better for you to contest it with me with min than with menaces.
Upon my faith you are a funny mortal, my Strabax. Prithee, do proceed----  A fool and a madman are contending for their ruin; I'm all right.

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: Come, younker, do you offer something first.

sp.speaker: STRABAX
sp.p: Why no; do you squander first, and come to ruin.

p.#text: . Well, here's a talent of silver for you. It's in Philippean coins. Take it for yourself.
. So much the better. Be one of our family, but live at your own expense.

note.#text: :  "Solve zonam." Literally, "loosen your girdle." The girdle was sometimes used as the purse itself. At other times the purse was placed there for safety

p.#text: . Where is that which you are going to give? Open your purse-strings.

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: That's a challenge.

p.#text: . What are you afraid of?

note.#text: :  He alludes to the alleged service of Stratophanes in the Babylonian army, and implies that he hesitates to answer to the challenge because he does not know whether Stratophanes may not turn out to be a sharper.

p.#text: You are from abroad. I live here . I am afraid.

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: I am not. Walk off, then.

sp.speaker: STRABAX
sp.p: I'm bringing her some sheep fastened in a purse to my neck.

note.#text: :  Stratophanes plumes himself with the idea that, he having given the money to Phronesium, the other will not dare to answer his challenge.

p.#text: Because I gave that, how I did flounder the fellow.

sp.speaker: STRABAX
sp.p: Why no, indeed, it's I, who am going to give.

p.#text: . Come in-doors now, prithee, and  do you then stay with me here.

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: You will give me your company then?

p.#text: . What say you?

sp.speaker: PHRONESIUM
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: STRABAX
sp.p: What do you say? What, with this fellow? Am I to be postponed?

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: I have made my present.

p.#text: . You have given;  he's going to give just now; the one I've got, the other I expect. But each of the two shall be indulged to his heart's content.

sp.speaker: STRABAX
sp.p: So be it. As I see the matter stands, that must be taken that's offered.

sp.speaker: STRATOPHANES
sp.p: Indeed, I shall assuredly not be letting you take possession of my couch.

note.#text: :  There has been some doubt as to the meaning of this and the next two lines; but, on examination, it is clear that they have an indecent signification.

:  Cicero, in his Treatise "On Old Age," informs us that this Play was a favourite one of Plautus. It is difficult to see for what reason, as, compared with many of the others, it seems to be deficient in plot, and the Churl. from whom it takes its name has scarcely, any part in the business of it.

p.#text: . I' faith, I've cleverly netted them, and quite to my satisfaction.  And as I see my affairs successfully managed, yours likewise would I successfully manage. I'll caress you in reality. If you are disposed to be doing anything, take care, will you, and let me know at once. For the sake of Venus, applaud; this Play is in her honor. Spectators, kindly farewell; grant applause, and then rise up.
